passages.text: Emerging Europe Europe
Telecommunications Wireless Services
Date 29 August 2025 Periodical

Over the last week (Thu to Thu) the telecoms sector outperformed the broader market, with the SXKP index down \(0.5\%\) while the STOXX index was down \(1.0\%\) The strongest performers amongst the SXKP constituents were Sunrise \((+5.3\%)\) Cellnex \((+3.7\%)\) and BT Group \((+2.5\%)\) while the weakest performers were Telecom Italia \((- 9.9\%)\) Orange \((- 5.0\%)\) and Swisscom \((- 3.2\%)\) .Over the week, the sector risk- free rate decreased by - 6bps to \(4.2\%\) \((+4bps\) ytd).YTD the forex move had a negative impact of - 61bps on sector EBITDA \((+17bps\) w- o- w).

\*Reminder: TMT Conference 3 and 4 September\* We are hosting our \(29^{\text{th}}\) TMT conference at our offices in London on 3 and 4 September (in- person only). This is a great opportunity to meet a number of companies including 1&1, BT, Cellnex, DT, Eutelsat, Freenet, Helios, NOS, OTE, INWIT, KPN, Liberty Global, Orange, Proximus, Sunrise, Telecom Italia, Telefonica, Telenor, Vodafone and Zegona. Please register and complete your meeting requests
Key telecom topics and events this week

TMT CONFERENCE COMPENDIUM: Telecoms edition. We look forward to welcoming you to our 29th TMT Conference at our offices on the 3rd and 4th of September, 2025. The event will bring together investors and more than 60 corporates from all corners of Telecoms, Media and Technology. We hope that you have a very fruitful two days and we look forward to helping you with your investment decisions. Link to note

BT GROUP (Sell): Curb your enthusiasm - OR losses seasonal, not inflectional. Keep Sell. Q1 26 saw Openreach line losses surprise (still- 169k) boosting sentiment around the alt- net threat. We note that line losses have seasonal tendencies and Q1 more a delayed hiatus than a new trend. We expect further deterioration due to the lagged impact of alt- net build, the move by Sky to sell on CityFibre, and the attempts of a myriad alt- net to improve customer growth (via price, speed, wholesale and consolidation). We further see risks to BT in mobile from Vodafone Three and high- end MVNOs with B2B continuing to be tough (Daisy/VM02, Vorbus etc). Keep Sell. Link to note.

FRENCH TELECOMS: Slowing French volumes impacting growth. Iliad Q2 group rev EUR 2,551m (+3.3% y- o- y, Q1 +4.3%, Q4 +5.1%). In France, the mobile base was stable (essentially +0k) vs. Q1 +5k (Q4 +50k), with management citing limited

commercial activity. France MSR growth (billed to subs) \(+0.2\%\) y- o- y, vs. Q1 \(+1.4\%\) (Q4 \(+6.1\%\) ), reflecting the lower volume environment, higher competition and convergent discount. Investors remain focused on competitive dynamics in the French retail market. Iliad continues to see a positive mix shift effect within Consumer with a (very) small decrease in voice based plans, and ongoing migration from the Free plan to the unlimited 4G/5G plan (now \(76.7\%\) , vs. \(76.4\%\) in Q1, \(76.1\%\) in Q4), no ARPU breakdown given this quarter. Orange's message last month highlighted the market was exhibiting limited top- line growth, reflective in their flat to small positive retail service revenue growth outlook for FY25 in the absence of a broad price increase. Net adds were strong for Orange (both mobile and fixed) but these subscribers are coming on at a lower pricing point. Whilst the upper end of the market (broadband and convergence) remains solid, it is more the low end that has experienced competitive tension, although Orange said July had seen limited promotions. Call at 1pm UK and expect questions on the potential for France in- market consolidation. Link to note.

ITALIAN TELECOMS: Comments from the Iliad Q2 call: (1) Consolidation: Iliad said it had 'serious discussions' with TI but no discussions since April and that these will not resume. It argues that 2025 will be the turning point for Iliad Italy's FCF generation with Italy now self- funding; (2) Mobile growth: Iliad is happy with its net adds momentum and the company argues there is limited impact from the win- back offers from competitors, and with Iliad leading on NPS; (3) Broadband growth: acknowledges broadband growth could be better but the company has been reliant on availability of wholesale FTTH, but still with net adds better than competitors. OVERALL: On the Q1 call, Iliad said there were no discussions in Italy but yesterday's comments were firmer in saying that discussions will also not resume. This could mean there is no scope for consolidation, or that it may happen but Iliad does not want to appear desperate for a deal ahead of negotiations or that a deal is instead more likely with WindTre than TI. The market has been hopeful of consolidation, leaving TI sensitive to the end outcome- we have the TICEO and CFO at our TMT conference next week. Link to Friday's daily

FX: Among major currencies vs. EURO, USD \(+49bps\) w- o- w (- 665bps ytd), GBP \(+24bps\) w- o- w (- 239bps ytd), CHF \(+35bps\) w- o- w (+ 1bps ytd), NOK \(+12bps\) w- o- w (+ 71bps ytd), SEK \(+13bps\) w- o- w (+ 311bps ytd), and BRL \(+63bps\) w- o- w (+ 121bps ytd).
BONDS: 1) Tele2 has issued 2 bonds of SEK 850m & 400m with a coupon of \(3.0\%\) & \(2.8\%\) respectively, maturing at Sep' 2030 each.
2) Orange has issued EUR 900m bond of coupon \(3.75\%\) , maturing at Sep' 2030.

TELCO: DB equity strategist Max Uleer has downgraded his European telco sector rating from neutral to underweight citing recent outperformance, that as a defensive it is likely to underperform an improving cyclical environment and that valuations have moved beyond 10- year averages (see here). We agree that telcos are defensive to trade wars, will benefit less from a cyclical recovery and are less cheap than they were. However, we also note that the last 10 years has seen a once in a multi- generation investment in fibre which is now seeing capex fall and after 25 years of regulatory policy in favour of at least 4 mobile operators in each market, the EC may be shifting in favour of allowing consolidation without the structural remedies which have harmed the sector for some time. We also note that historical sector multiples are distorted by lease accounting (a major impact for the telcos) and some big ticket M&A / increased US footprint weighting (i.e. European telcos are cheaper ex DT's increased US exposure). In our view, improving revenue growth, reducing costs, increasing cash returns and some still very cheap valuations warrants ongoing investor interest at a potentially still- early stage of sector rehabilitation (after many years in the investor wilderness!). Further falling rates, at some point, should support 'bond proxy' telcos (see our Outlook 2025). Post a substantial sector rally, stock picking is now more important than ever and some telcos are at unsupportable valuations.
29 August 2025 Wireless Services DB X- Connect
The sector has a total return potential of \(17.6\%\)

The sector offers a potential of \(17.6\%\) total return opportunity to our targets. The sector on average trades at a 2025E EV/EBITDA of \(7.4x\) , P/E of \(30x\) , dividend yield of \(4.3\%\) , and ECF yield of \(6.6\%\) (see Figure 1). The key risks we see for the sector include a weak macro environment and regulatory/competitive pressures.

Over the last week (Thu to Thu) the telecoms sector outperformed the broader market, with the SXKP index down \(0.5\%\) while the STOXX index was down \(1.0\%\) .
The strongest performers amongst the SXKP constituents were Sunrise \((+5.3\%)\) , Cellnex \((+3.7\%)\) , and BT Group \((+2.5\%)\) .
The weakest performers amongst the SXKP constituents were Telecom Italia \((- 9.9\%)\) , Orange \((- 5.0\%)\) , and Swisscom \((- 3.2\%)\) .

Outside the index the best performers were United Internet \((+4.2\%)\) , 1&1 \((+4.0\%)\) , and Zegona \((+3.6\%)\) while the worst performers were Bouygues \((- 4.9\%)\) , Telekom Austria \((- 2.1\%)\) , and OTE \((- 1.7\%)\) .

TELCO: DB equity strategist Max Uleer has downgraded his European telco sector rating from neutral to underweight citing recent outperformance, that as a defensive it is likely to underperform an improving cyclical environment and that valuations have moved beyond 10- year averages (see here). Link to daily
TELEFONICA / ZEGONA: El Confidencial reported that the cornerstone of Telefonica's upcoming strategic plan is to purchase Vodafone Spain (owned by Zegona). Link to daily

TELEFONICA: Telefonica Deutschland has made changes to O2 prepaid, with all customers now getting access to 5G and an increase in the max speed once customers use up their data allowance, to 1Mbps from 384 Kbps. Link to daily
ZEGONA announced it will hold its AGM on 24 September and a list of proposals has been published ahead of this. Link to daily

1&1 announced that United Internet has purchased a further EUR 45m of shares in 1&1 at a price of EUR 18.70 per share (voluntary offer to the 1&1 minorities was carried out at EUR 18.50). Link to daily
SUNRISE launched a Home Security product range, continuing its push into adjacent markets (travel and cyber insurance launched in July). Link to daily
SALT (n/r): Q2 25 investor call feedback. Link to daily

INWIT: As part of its EUR 300m (c.3% market cap) FY25 share buyback, during the week 18 August, INWIT purchased 1.1m shares at an average price of EUR 10.47 (previous week 0.9m at EUR 10.41). Link to daily
FRENCH TELCOS / ORANGE: On Iliad's Q2 call there wasn't anything incremental on potential consolidation in the French market. Link to daily
FRENCH TELCOS: Prime Minister Bayrou called for a confidence vote as he seeks to force support for his budget plan that would foresee EUR 44bn of fiscal tightening. Link to daily

FRENCH TELCOS / ORANGE: As we enter the back to school promotion period, Alloforfait reported that this week the main operators have now all deployed a strategy of free fibre activation fees. Link to daily
ITALIAN TELCOS: Iliad Italy reported Q2 mobile service revenue growth +5.8% (Q1 +7.2%, Q4 +9.8%) and EBITDAa Growth +34.2% (Q1 +24.4%, Q4 +31.0%). Link to daily
ITALIAN TELCOS / TELECOM ITALIA: Comments from the Iliad Q2 call. Link to daily

BELGIAN TELCOS: Earlier this week De Tijd reported that Citymesh, one of Digi Belgium's shareholders, is in talks with potential shareholders and banks about a cash injection of more than EUR 60m. Link to daily

SATELLITE / EUTELSAT: Advanced Television reported that the SpaceRISE consortium, which is managing the IRIS2 EU wide LEO constellation, has launched its first tender for the building of the 270- satellite LEO segment of the scheme. Link to daily

SATELLITE: As we reported (see daily), two suppliers, Aerospacelab of Belgium and Airbus Defense & Space of France, are competing for the first IRIS2 tender process for the LEO constellation. Link to daily

Curb your enthusiasm - OR losses seasonal, not inflectional. Keep Sell.

Q1 26 saw Openreach line losses surprise (still - 169k) boosting sentiment around the alt- net threat. We note that line losses have seasonal tendencies and Q1 more a delayed hiatus than a new trend. We expect further deterioration due to the lagged impact of alt- net build, the move by Sky to sell on CityFibre, and the attempts of a myriad alt- nets to improve customer growth (via price, speed, wholesale and consolidation). We further see risks to BT in mobile from VodafoneThree and high- end MVNOs with B2B continuing to be tough (Daisy/VMO2, Vorbus etc). Keep Sell.

Alt- net build rates have slowed but their focus on customers is growing. These networks which will pass close to 20m UK premises at end- 25 are not disappearing indeed CityFibre's \((4.5m +\) prems) f2.3bn of new funding highlights that alt- net access to capital is far from closed. Acquisition of customers is the new priority (Community Fibre now offers symmetric 500bps for f20/month) with increasing wholesale (inc Netomnia with \(2.5m +\) prems) and Community Fibre has signed V3 as a retail ISP. Sky \((- 6m\) BB subs) selling on CityFibre from this summer is material.

Openreach line losses typically improve in Q3 post the back- to- school rush and ahead of a Christmas slowdown (no- one wants to be without internet then!). This seasonal hiatus for Q3 25 was likely pushed out due to the launch of OTS last Sep (a 'liquidity event' for alt- nets), a focus on value at VMO2 and a customer push at BT Consumer (ARPUs have slowed). BT has not changed its expectation for 900k losses in FY26 and despite the better Q1 out- turn investors should remain cautious.

We were too early to d/g BT on 7 May- the stock is up \(28\%\) since (54% ytd TSR). The sector helped (pure telcos \(+25\%\) ytd) but not since early May. Trade buying is a factor but closer to ending and Carlos Slim has started selling. The Co. targets f3bn of NFC by FY30 but that excludes restructuring and pensions with the near- term less idyllic (capex brought forward) and the longer- term subject to higher taxes and stronger competitors (mobile and fixed) limiting capex decline. We see more risks and less reward for BT vs peers. Sell. TP unch. (DCF based, WACC \(7\%\) , TGR \(0.3\%\) ). With regard relative valuation we note that UK10Ys yield \(4.8\%\) vs sector \(\sim 4.2\%\) (inc EM) and \(\sim 3\%\) for peers. Upside risks: FTSE100/UK10Y and further sector re- rating.

Slowing French volumes hampers growthIlliad Q2 group revs EUR 2,551m (+3.3% y- o- y, Q1 +4.3%, Q4 +5.1%). In France, the mobile base was stable (essentially +0k) vs. Q1 +5k (Q4 +50k), with management citing limited commercial activity. France MSR growth (billed to subs) +0.2% y- o- y, vs. Q1 +1.4% (Q4 +6.1%), reflecting the lower volume environment, higher competition and convergent discount. Investors remain focused on competitive dynamics in the French retail market. Iliad continues to see a positive mix shift effect within Consumer with a (very) small decrease in voice based plans, and ongoing migration from the Free plan to the unlimited 4G/5G plan (now 76.7%, vs. 76.4% in Q1, 76.1% in Q4), no ARPU breakdown given this quarter. Orange's message last month highlighted the market was exhibiting limited top- line growth, reflective in their flat to small positive retail service revenue growth outlook for FY25 in the absence of a broad price increase. Net adds were strong for Orange (both mobile and fixed) but these subscribers are coming on at a lower pricing point. Whilst the upper end of the market (broadband and convergence) remains solid, it is more the low end that has experienced competitive tension, although Orange said July had seen limited promotions. Call at 1pm UK and expect questions on the potential for France in- market consolidation.

Headlines: Total group revs in Q2 EUR 2,551m (+3.3% y- o- y, Q1 +4.3%, Q4 +5.1%). France revs EUR 1,640m (+1.8% y- o- y, Q1 +3.0%, Q4 +5.4%). Within the mix, France mobile service revs (billed to subs) were EUR 569m (+0.2% y- o- y, Q1 +1.4%, Q4 +6.1%). Fixed service revs EUR 927m (+2.3% y- o- y, Q1 +6.2%, Q4 +6.3%). Q2 France EBITDAEUR 733m (+10.7% y- o- y, Q1 +0.9%, Q4 +0.2%), which was supported by a higher contribution from the build to suit program.

KPIs: In France, Iliad reported 0k mobile net adds in Q2 (Q1 +5k, Q4 +50k), o/w flat 4G/5G plans (Q1 +48k, Q4 +99k). Broadband net adds flat (Q1 +3k, Q4 +5k), c. +100k fibre net adds (Q1 +114k, Q4 +111k), fibre take- up 84.5% (Q1 83.2%, Q4 81.7%). For ORA Q2 24, mobile contract (ex M2M) net adds +116k vs. Q4 +4k. FTTH net adds +270k (Q1 +282k) and BB adds +29k (Q1 +2k), and Bouygues(n/r) Q1 mobile postpaid net adds ex- M2M came in at +43k (Q1 +63k), +95k fibre net adds (Q1 +148k) and +36k BB net adds (Q1 +69k).

Echostar announced a transaction this morning to sell its \(3.45MHz\) and \(600MHz\) spectrum to AT&T for \(\) 23B\(- 50MHz\) in total), in addition to amending their MVNO agreement, making it a "hybrid MNO relationship" whereby Boost will continue to use its cloud native 5G core, while AT&T's sites will become the primary RAN for Boost. The deal is expected to close in mid- 2026. Our key takeaways from today's announcement are summarized below.

This transaction should net SATS \(\) 21B\(after taxes, relative to the company's current net debt of\) \ \(23B\) and gross debt of \(\) 27B\(. This transaction, if completed, will instantly resolve SATS' balance sheet and liquidity challenges. Our current PT values these spectrum bands at\) \ \(13B\) which was admittedly conservative, meaning that this sale should net proceeds of \(\) 8B\(above our valuation, or\) \ \(23\) per share. The deal represents a good price for both companies, in our view. We estimate the transaction implies \(\) 1.53\(per MHz\) * POP. AT&T will be able to deploy this spectrum in its network with minimal incremental capital expenditures and any incremental capex that is required should be offset by savings from cell splitting (AT&T stated it will deploy the spectrum within its multi- year capex guidance today). There are likely more spectrum sales in the pipeline. SATS, in its press release, states that this sale is a critical step toward resolving the FCC's concerns over spectrum utilization and that "We continue to evaluate strategic opportunities for our remaining spectrum portfolio in partnership with the U.S. government and wireless industry participants." Applying the \(\) 1.53\(per MHz\) * POP to SATS' AWS- 4, H- Block, and AWS- 3 licenses implies another\) \ \(34B\) in gross proceeds, or an estimated \(\) 29B\(post- tax\) \ \(85\) per share post- tax). SATS also owns some \(700MHz\) and CBRS licenses, which we're not including in the aforementioned estimates, but aren't that material and we think would be harder to monetize. From an AT&T perspective, this transaction will significantly enhance AT&T's spectrum position and network performance, and it can be immediately deployed by AT&T because AT&T has the option to lease the spectrum pending the sale. The purchase will increase AT&T's financial leverage, but AT&T has still reiterated all of its financial guidance and capital returns targets. Implications for Other Industry Players: We see today's announcement as having directionally negative implications for towers (due to Boost RAN decommissioning) and for cable (due to the creation of incremental capacity at AT&T for fixed wireless). It also makes AT&T more competitive against T- Mobile and Verizon, and we think adds some pressure on Verizon specifically to add to its spectrum portfolio.
Published on 26 Aug 2025
More Value Unlock Potential To Come
We See Today's Announcement As A Very Big First Step By Echostar To Unlock Shareholder Value

Today's announced \(\) 22.65\(Sale of spectrum to AT&T (by Echostar) will provide Echostar with an enormous injection of needed liquidity upon closing; giving the company flexibility to pay down debt and invest in its recently announced NTN/ LEO constellation, while also unlocking significant shareholder value. Today's announcement also represents a step toward satisfying the FCC's concerns regarding the under utilization of SATS' spectrum licenses and the agency's desire to see SATS sell spectrum to companies that will be able to put the licenses to more productive use in serving the public's appetite for connectivity services.

We are increasing our PT to \(\) 67\(, from\) \ \(43\) , driven by: (1) greater value being assigned to the retail wireless business now that SATS is signaling that it will decommission its wireless network, thus improving profitability; (2) The elimination of capital investment into the company's terrestrial wireless network; and (3) a shorter period of time assumed to realize the value of SATS' 3.45 GHz, 600 MHz, and AWS- 3 spectrum bands (we now assume 1 year, vs 2.5 years previously).

We believe this \(\) 23\$ B pending sale of spectrum to AT&T, combined with ongoing pressure from the FCC on SATS to sell spectrum, will lead to further actions by SATS that will unlock shareholder value and propel the stock higher in the coming months. These include: (1) Additional spectrum sales, namely AWS- 3; (2) Revisiting a DISH Network- DIRECTV merger (recall that the previous merger agreement had been canceled by DIRECTV and its owner, TPG, after DISH failed to complete a deleveraging debt exchange); and (3) the potential for capital returns, including a special dividend or share repurchases. We also see the potential, longer term, for the monetization of SATS' 700 MHz and CBRS bands.

We see additional optionality from the potential for SATS to monetize its AWS- 4 bands, as well as the smaller H- Block, which is effectively an extension of AWS- 4. Our \(\) 67\$ PT values SATS' AWS- 4 and H- Block bands at \(\) 0.00\$ per MHz\*POP because our base case assumption is that SATS will continue to pursue the build- out of its recently announced LEO constellation, rather than selling this spectrum. That being said, we don't know whether the FCC will insist on SATS selling AWS- 4. It seems logical that selling 3.45 GHz, 600 MHz, and AWS- 3 would satisfy the FCC, but we just don't know for sure. It is also possible that SATS will voluntarily sell half of its AWS- 4 and keep the other half for NTN/LEO, although we don't think this is likely unless the FCC insists since the spectrum would be valuable for the LEO business and could always be monetized later if SATS found that it doesn't need all of it. A leasing relationship or partnership is also a possibility, although not our most likely case.

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.

The risk of loss in futures trading and options, foreign or domestic, can be substantial.
